title: Great white sharks' terrifying jaws captured in incredible underwater photos
text:

'Crazy' shark photographer Euan Rannachan used to curse the fearsome creatures which prevented him from diving.

But now he captures them on camera after his annoyance turned into an artistic obsession.

He has revealed his latest jaw-dropping images, a powerful collection of the moments he has come face-to-face with the deep-sea predators.

The fearless British snapper has a new-found respect for the incredible species after years of being unable to step foot in the water.

His images show the gaping mouths of the sharks off Guadeloupe Island, Mexico.

(Image: Mediadrumimages/EuanRannachan/@E)

(Image: Mediadrumimages/EuanRannachan/@E)

London-born Euan says adrenaline fuels his need to get as close as he can as he shoots just feet away from the teeth.

These amazing pictures show why being unable to dive in certain areas of the world is a small price to pay.

The snapper, who has lived in California for the past 15 years, spoke about how he gets such great shots earlier this year.

(Image: Mediadrumimages/EuanRannachan/@E)

(Image: Mediadrumimages/EuanRannachan/@E)

“We have these people on the boat called shark wranglers and they throw these two-foot chunks of tuna and get the shark close to the surface," he explained.

“We probably have the best shark wrangler in the world, a guy named Crazy Luis, and he stays up on the boat bring the shark to us when we sit on the surface in the shark cage.

“Sometimes when the wranglers play with the sharks, the sharks get p****d off and dive down under the boat and the bait so they can come rocketing up and get it.

(Image: Mediadrumimages/EuanRannachan/@E)

(Image: Mediadrumimages/EuanRannachan/@E)

"It was really deep there but the water clarity was amazing, and I just happened to be in the right spot seeing her coming up.

“I get myself in the front of the cage."
description: Fearless British photographer Euan Rannachan went up close and personal with the beast off Guadeloupe Island in Mexico
